case_vignette: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in his mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year at high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of his oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been suffering from painful sores in my mouth for the past four days.
Have you noticed any similar sores or blisters on other parts of your body, such as your hands or genitals?
No, I have never had any sores on my genitals or anywhere else, just in my mouth.
Do the sores inside your mouth appear as ulcers with a red border and a white or yellow center?
Yes, they look like that.
How many sores do you currently have in your mouth?
The information about the number of sores wasn't provided to me.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms like fever, difficulty swallowing, or swollen lymph nodes?
No, I don't have any of those symptoms, just a slight fever.
Have you had similar mouth sores in the past?
Yes, I've had similar sores twice in the past year.
Do you have any known autoimmune conditions or illnesses that could contribute to mouth sores?
I am otherwise healthy and don't have any known conditions like that.
Final Diagnosis: Recurrent aphthous stomatitis (canker sores).
